pros:
This is hard for me to write, because when I joined this organization, under the leadership of the previous, much-loved CEO, I believed that I was part of an exceptionally well-run shop, helping to build capacity in tandem with people who need it most, contributing to something great. When I left, I felt as though I was leaving an organization struggling to escape a long and painful downward spiral.

When the prior CEO left, the new CEO made changes and permitted (and continues to permit) hires that made me shake my head. Sure, they looked great on paper. In practice? Underqualified, ruthless, arrogant, eager to change for the sake of change yet unwilling to embrace the learnings of people who've been in the realm of international development (a hugely complex arena) for many years. 

These new leaders, coupled with some old ones who had been around forever and are now mercifully gone, made was was a time of stagnation on the child sponsorship front into a period of rapid descent, from which the organization has yet to recover. Yes, donors are changing. Yes, they are more cynical, younger, require more demonstrable impact, fewer events, and better stewardship. But their collective hearts for the work remain the same. People didn't stop giving because they don't love supporting the work, they stopped giving because the organization failed to demonstrate why their support matters. WVC stopped meeting the needs of the changing landscape and that's on senior leadership, full stop.
cons: Senior leadership. Poor new hires at the senior level.

review_title: An expose would be fair but devastating
pros: There are many, many well-meaning individuals working at World Vision Canada. The employees on the programs side of the organization are world-class in their function as international development experts. Truly they are innovative and effective in their fight against systemic poverty and injustice.
cons:
There are all of the lies, politics, cliques and misguided decision making any major organization with mediocre leadership has. There also exists a far worse element. I am not sure how this is even legal by today's employment standards in Canada. 

No openly gay individual or practitioner of a religion other than Christianity is welcome to work at World Vision.  Though World Vision does not discriminate about who they take donations from, any non-Christian individuals, or individuals with a background that is not Christian who sneaks through the hiring process will be made uncomfortable and eventually unwelcome. 

This is easily proven by a section in every employee's annual performance evaluation that evaluates how Christ-centric they are. The Christ-centric evaluation directly affects an employee's salary.

Publicly, the organization would deny it discriminates. I invite any and all reading this to investigate my claims independently. If an openly atheist, muslim, hindu, sikh, or member of the LGBTQ community can gain employment at World Vision and comfortably last 18 months practicing their beliefs or lifestyle while employed at World Vision Canada, I will gladly retract this statement and issue an apology.
